awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Semiconducting Behavior in Silsesquioxane Macromonomers and Polymers
awd_abstract_narration:
With support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professors Richard Laine and John Kieffer of the University of Michigan-Ann Arbor, and Professor Aleks Rebane of Montana State University will develop new families of silicone-based polymers. Silicone oils and rubbers are hydrophobic, colorless, and electrically insulating materials and as such find wide uses. Recently, two families of silicon-containing polymers were developed wherein silicon-containing building blocks alternate with fluorescent ones. Unlike most known silicon-based materials, these polymers are intensely colored, brightly fluorescent, and behave as semiconductors. Importantly, they still retain key properties of traditional silicones, such as water and flame resistance. Semiconducting polymers, such as, organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) are found in flat panel displays and in some instances can be used to convert sunlight into electricity. Hence the study of these new polymer families could lead to unexpected and potentially useful properties, bringing new, low-cost and more robust materials to many everyday societal applications. This research project will facilitate the training of graduate and undergraduate students to expand knowledge of these materials and their behavior. 

Silsesquioxanes (SQs) are unique, regularly symmetric 3D macromolecules that resemble single silica crystals  in being extremely robust, some remaining air-stable up to 600 °C. The phenyl derivatives of SQs can also be selectively functionalized by using electrophilic substitution reactions. The cage centers interact with appended moieties in the excited state providing 3D conjugation (cage centered LUMOs) and semiconducting behavior. There is potential to develop new families of polymers with semiconducting properties wherein siloxane bridges offer potential value for photonic applications, for example for displays, hybrid lasers and photovoltaics. These avenues of scientific inquiry, which constitute the basis for the broad collaboration, aim at expanding the number of cage architectures that form the presumed cage centered LUMOs, detailing the substitution patterns required to promote onset of such properties, and optimizing one- and two-photon quantum efficiencies for display, white light and laser applications. These goals will be pursued through detailed photophysical measurements, theoretical modeling, and electrochemical probing with the aim of improving fundamental understanding of structure-property relationships in this polymer family. The potential exists to make available important new sets of semiconducting polymers for chemists, physicists and materials scientists and engineers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for NSF Grant No. CHE 2103602

Collaborative Research: Semiconducting Behavior in Silsesquioxane Macromonomers and Polymers

Richard M. Laine,1,2 John Kieffer,1 Aleks Rebane3

Department of Materials Science and Engineering.1 Macromolecular Science and Engineering,2 University of Michigan; Dept of Physics, Montana State University.3

 

 

Polymeric materials that conduct electricity (electrons and holes) have become a part of our everyday society as they have been used and continue to be used to generate the red, green and blue colors in flat panel displays, and in almost everyone’s cell phone.  They are also used as conducting coatings that can eliminate static electricity from building up, thereby protecting electronic circuitry. In the same vein, such polymers have been applied to metals to control electrochemical potentials thereby protecting for example aircraft parts from corrosion.

There are also examples of such polymers being used as photovoltaics that transform sunlight to electricity. Essentially all such polymers rely on delocalizing electronic interactions along the polymer chain (backbone)—spreading them across the entire length of the chain allowing electronic communication between one end of the chain and the other as well as between chains. The degree of communication controls for example the band gap which in turn controls what light is emitted (red, green, blue) or absorbed from sunlight. Commercially important polymers usually rely on carbon-carbon double bonds to establish extended conjugation.

In contrast, polymers that have silicon-oxygen-silicon (Si-O-Si) links in their chains (silicone oils and rubbers) are well known for their insulating properties and indeed are used commercially as insulating materials everywhere in our society.

In the work undertaken in this recently finished research effort, we synthesized families of such polymers wherein every other Si-O-Si unit is separated by a conjugated unit, as found in traditional conducting polymers. One would normally assume that the presence of multiple Si-O-Si units in a polymeric backbone would again lead to insulating/non-conducting polymers. However, much to our surprise, this is not the case and in fact, the new families of co-polymers behave much the same as traditional conjugated polymers.  That is, they also can absorb and emit light with wavelengths that depend on the length of the polymer chain (called degree of polymerization, DP). The longer the chain (DP) the more red (less blue) the emission. Sometimes with unoptimized efficiencies emitted/absorbed light >60 %, competitive with traditional conjugated polymers.

Perhaps most surprising, after multiple efforts to explain why this happens, through extensive theoretical modeling, we have identified a rather novel type of molecular physics wherein normal Si-O-Si bonds typically have bonds to silicon that are much like C-C bond angles of 109° at 110-111° in model compounds made here that change in the copolymers such that we now find bond angles ranging from 130 to 155 °. This flattening of the bond angle is a result of a very rare form of conjugation normally found only in polymers with multiple Si-Si bonds, but never Si-O-Si bonds. This type of bonding is known as sigma-sigma* conjugation.

The end result is that we have discovered and prepared a large family of copolymers with multiple Si-O-Si units in the backbone that exhibit conjugation where previously it was thought that such units would impart insulating properties. Moreover, as a test of our findings, we have synthesized the first examples of copolymers with Si-NH-Si units in the backbone. These new materials, polysilazanes, also show what photophysical analyses suggest is sigma-sigma* conjugation but somewhat better than found with the Si-O-Si DP equivalent copolymers. Much more work must be done to expand these very unexpected results that may allow such polymers to be used with or in place of traditionally conjugated polymers. It is reasonable to expect that sets of properties may be identified that differ from traditional conjugated polymers.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/05/2025
Modified by: Richard Laine

Project Outcomes Report for NSF Grant No. CHE 2103602


Collaborative Research: Semiconducting Behavior in Silsesquioxane Macromonomers and Polymers


Richard M. Laine,1,2 John Kieffer,1 Aleks Rebane3


Department of Materials Science and Engineering.1 Macromolecular Science and Engineering,2 University of Michigan; Dept of Physics, Montana State University.3








Polymeric materials that conduct electricity (electrons and holes) have become a part of our everyday society as they have been used and continue to be used to generate the red, green and blue colors in flat panel displays, and in almost everyones cell phone.
